[h1]Wait for DLC or Buy On Sale[/h1]
Frost Punk 2 has several significant issues and it is hard for me to recommend the game to anyone who is a major fan of Frost Punk 1.  Overall the game is not bad, and many aspects are actually very good but there are several major pain points the drag the current state of the game down.

[b]Minor contextual spoilers ahead, you have been warned[/b]

[h2]Tutorials (or lack thereof)[/h2]
The story starts with what seems to be the intended tutorial but really the chapter is barely able to be called a tutorial.  This is mainly because the opening chapter only covers a small fraction of the game with the rest of the tutorial tucked away in a purely text/image tutorial window.  This tutorial documentation is actually good and does a decent job of explaining the remaining aspects of the game, but it is so detached from the rest of the game that I would be surprised if most players open it, as is up to the player to break out of the immersion of the game to read the tutorial documentation.  It is completely breaking of the game, and really a failure on 11-bit's part to not integrate the tutorial better.  The sad part is, we known they can integrate a tutorial into the natural flow of the game as that is how Frost Punk 1 worked.  Small pop-ups and events that happen in Frost Punk 1 guide the player and introduce new mechanics in a natural and well defined way, but sadly Frost Punk 2 forgoes all of this, instead condemning the player to break their immersion and spent time reading the tutorial instead of playing the game.

[h2]UI (Why is Everything White?)[/h2]
For a game that is set on largely white background, with largely white features, it is strange that the UI is also largely white or grey.  Generally, it is hard to read the, otherwise very gorgeous and well done UI, because everything just tends to blend into each other.  [spoiler]For instance, frost breaking, the act of breaking up the snow/ice so you can build there, requires the users to select tiles that are marked bright white, from tiles that either grey (already broken) or not as bright white (not accessible tiles).[/spoiler]  I generally am not sure how a visually impaired person is able to play this game as so many elements of the UI just blend in with each other.

The game does come with a dark mode, but the developers decided to throw a warning in that turning on dark mode will result in a lost of UI look and feel.  I guess the devs are trying to warn that dark mode is not the intended way to play, but if that is truly the case then maybe the devs should re-evaluate why they felt the need to include dark mode in the first place.  Additionally, for some reason dark mode does degrade some of the few colored elements in the UI, to monotone colors, which just seems completely unnecessary.  

[h2]Performance (Another New Game, Another Example of Terrible Launch Performance)[/h2]
The game tricks the user into thinking that the game will perform well as the initial half of a play through tends to play very well.  Movement is fluid, clicks are responsive, and saves are not disruptive, but somewhere around the half way point everything starts to fall apart.  

Take saving, the game defaults to auto-saving at regular intervals and, importantly, the game is completely frozen while a save is happening.  At first, this minor inconvenience as the auto-save will freeze the game for a second and is generally not an issue, but as the city grows the time it takes to save also grows.  This ultimately culminates in 30+ second long save times when in the late game (all saves are to SSDs).  This is exasperated by the auto-save feature which makes it very frustrating to be dealing with a crisis in the game and then suddenly everything stops, you can't click on anything, you can't do anything, but look at the "<saving...>" window and wait, and wait, and wait....  The save performance completely breaks the immersion, and I ultimately thought about turning off auto-saves because it was so disruptive, but doing so would have made the random crashes much more painful.

What would a game launch be without random, game breaking, crashes, and Frost Punk 2 has them in spades.  I will not go into all the issues the Mac community is having as I do not play on a Mac, but they are many and loud on the discord.  No, instead I will focus on my, and my partners, Windows play through.  There appears to be an issues with the game crashing when playing at max speed, and while I did not encounter many crashes, my partner did and they where to the point that they needed to save frequently (remember the save issue, yea, it is even worst when combined with the crashes).  The only main difference between our two devices, I have an Intel CPU, and my partner has an AMD CPU, so maybe there is an issue with AMD CPUs but I do not know for certain.  All I can say is that the same is completely unstable and you are basically forced to play with auto-immersion-breaking-saving on. 

The bright side, 11-bit has been working on trying to resolve these issues and I am hopeful that the issues will be resolved with patches in the coming days/weeks.

[h2]Frost Punk Soul (Where did it go?)[/h2]
All of the above issues with the game can be resolved with patches and updates over time, but the by far the biggest issue with Frost Punk 2 is the [i]almost[/i] lack of soul.  One of the great things about FP 1 is the decisions a player has to make just in who works where, do the children work in the mines (which they yearn for) or does it fall to an automaton?  These kinda of intimate interactions are completely missing from the game, instead [spoiler]districts pull from a generic pool of workers, are they children? Maybe.  They could also be automatons or the elderly, who knows![/spoiler]  These interactions, and others, are what made FP 1 so great and also so hard, but achievable.  I have hard a lot of players say that FP 2 is so much harder than FP 1 ever was, but I do not feel like that difficulty is truly because the game is harder.  Instead, the game generally feels harder not because it is harder, but because the player has significantly less tools to deal with any given crisis.  [spoiler]Instead, the player is left to building districts and sending out exploration teams, while occasionally throwing some stubborn party a gift/punishment to keep them from trying to tear everything down.[/spoiler]  Ultimately, the only time I felt truly moved or emotional was the very end of the story, which presents the player with an almost deep philosophical dive into the what is means to create a "utopia".   This is really the heart of FP 2 issues, the new scale of the game means that the intimate details that made FP 1 great are completely lost, and I am not sure there is a good way that can be fixed without some major redesigns.

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
Generally, FP 2 is a good and unique city builder game, the additional content truly pushes the boundaries and fulfills some wishes of FP 1. Sadly FP 2 is not the gritty [b]survival[/b] city builder that FP 1, and that is why I have a hard time recommending this game anyone other than a purely city builder fan.  I really hope that 11-bit can find away to bring back in some the moral and heart felt soul of FP 1, but until then, FP 2 feel just like a shell of the greatness that is FP 1.

I think the problem with this one is the district system and gameplay mechanics makes city planning rather uninteresting. In the first game if something is well planned, you could temporarily at least be "ahead of the curve". In this installment, pretty much impossible at harder difficulty levels to have neutral or positive states across most of the supply categories, so you just constantly toggle which you want to get ahead in. Negative states don't feel that impactful. What I would expect is for things to fall apart, except not really. I had negative housing for the a long duration and what I would expect is hundreds to start dying, but it took too long for too little people to die.

Some of the gameplay needs improvement too. E.g.: "not enough workforce to build building", but I do have workforce, just not enough. If I have 99% of the necessary workforce for a building, I still want those 99% to do something not just sit around. So workaround is to temporarily turn something to lower efficiency %, use the extra workforce to build new building, then tune new building down to 99% and reallocate the 1% back to original building. Not fun. Old model was better. Queue them all up and if you queue too many that's your problem.

Say what you will, but I love building roads (which you can't do here).

Frostpunk 2 is not trying to be Frostpunk 1; this is not Frostpunk 1.5. This is Frostpunk 2; a proper sequel.

You'll see a lot of reviews on here complaining that this diverted too much from what made Frostpunk great and you'll see a lot of people saying that the changes made here go in the wrong direction. I disagree. This game is still VERY Frostpunk: the game throws you into the frostland and you must keep the generator running and supplies coming all while the people of your city bicker and complain about the direction you take the city. The political side of Frostpunk 2 is vastly expanded on; passing laws and pleasing factions are far more important this time around. It is a core fundamental aspect of this sequel to delve into the political landscape of your city and carefully pick and choose which laws are passed and which factions to support. The final chapter of the campaign was so intense I literally can't remember a time where a game like this got me to that level of engagement and immersion. 

You'll learn A LOT about how to progress more successfully with each new city you make, whether it be trying the campaign on harder difficulties or picking different maps in the Utopia mode. I've now gone through three runs each with varying levels of success: the first one being marginally successful just enough to get by, the second one being vastly successful ensuring that my city stands long after I die, and the third crumbling from existence because of my inability to rule it properly. This game's insistence on forcing you to learn is extremely engaging and it really is the key reason why I can see myself putting dozens of more hours into this. 

Exploring the frostland and building resource outposts, surviving the blizzards, and ensuring every faction has their voice heard all make for a gameplay system that constantly keeps you engaged and really never gives you a dull moment. Each new run on a new map presents new challenges and new opportunities. 

While many will be disappointed that this isn't the same as Frostpunk 1, I think the evolution made in this entry still makes it extremely engaging and I have high hopes for the future of this franchise.

The only problem game play loop I had was is when trying to deal with all the logistics (you're playing a supply chain & logistics game) as there was no easy way (UI) to get an overview of what building is producing what and what upgrades it was missing and what supplies it needed etc, or so I assumed!!! 

I figure it out though. If you go into a CITY, top right corner there is a drop down and you can pick various things, such as ZONES, IMPROVEMENTS, CRAFTERS & HARVESTERS and now you have a complete picture of what your city is doing and what needs to be assigned/upgraded/allocated etc perfectly fine and you can do it all there, you do not have to click on every individual building on the map (outside of the city menu) anymore (unless you want to of course). Now I really enjoy this part of the game!

Combat... not what I expected in a GOOD way! I though it would be another boring CIV 6 type fight but oh no! You will have to maneuver around your combat units/formations and since turns are happening simultaneously you might not even "catch" the enemy so easily as you might think heh heh.

Mobile/Fast units are quite nice, at least for the one war I had. It was something like 30 vs 30 totals units and it took around 25 turns to conclude it and the battle(s) were all over several zones etc. Think medieval /ancient type battles where it took armies a while to find favorable terrain and so forth. I like it. I need many more hours to learn everything there is about it. I think it's a bit more to it then what meets the eye (to be the best General/Tactician I can be heh heh)

It's a pretty game, that's for sure. I like it. I had zero problems with crashes or bugs. My FPS was around 35 once there was a lot of things on the map, but that was with everything on maxed out settings, so very beautiful. This is not a game where you need a boatload of FPS, you're playing a turned based game that requires no reaction time. The performance is perfectly acceptable on my PC! Your mileage may vary though.

Anyway, I'll keep playing the game until I've gone through all the acts and so forth and completed the game and I'll update my review (if needed) once done.

Victoria 3 is my favorite paradox game and it introduces the skeleton of an amazing game, but it had pretty rough UI navigability and was a bit bare bones on some features. After a year of updates all those problems got fixed and now Vicky 3 is fantastic. The devs are very active on the discord and are well aware of the UI issues in this game, as well as the features that need work, and they are funded for the entire first year to provide free updates to fix both.

So overall, I am enjoying the game as is, even if the UI is admittedly a bit rough, but I am excited for what the future holds with such responsive devs that are quick to listen to and work to address the players desires.

While the game definitely does have some issues with performance at the moment, it's honestly a really solid game.

The crafting is quite extensive and you can tell they put a lot of love into it, and it's particularly satisfying to see your civilization grow and develop, as opposed to say the Civ series which while fun in its own right, doesn't really demonstrate that besides the occasional house popping up here and there along with the buildings changing depending on the technological age you're in.

The diplomacy is very basic, and definitely leaves a lot to be desired, but it's not any worse than Civ VI's. 

The battles aren't Total-War complex, but the formations feature allowing you to put units into a battalion together is quite a nice touch, I was worried it was going to just be "craft a unit and then send it out or whatever) but there is a basic aspect of tactical planning involved there, which I definitely hope to see expanded on in the future as well.

TL;DR It leaves a bit more to be desired in terms of complexity in other areas besides crafting, and is hampered by some launch day performance issues, but is overall a genuinely solid game.

Firstly, just to get this out of the way, I've got a beastly PC running it on max settings and I never had any performance issues so I can't speak much to that. This review will be solely on the gameplay and what I like and dislike about it.

Like:
-The realistic feel of city expansion and district manipulation. Civ always felt too abstract and board-game like especially civ 6. This game introduces a level of depth that's very pleasing to toy around with.
-The details of buildings, cities, with little people and units walking around and being able to zoom very far in to see a living world that makes you feel like youre actually playing through history.  It's a step civ has never taken and I always wished they would.
-The core gameplay loop of analyzing production chains, making choices to suit your city's needs, optimizing, crafting, etc. It scratches an itch the city builder and anno enjoyer side of me finds very pleasing. Toying with these systems to get a desired outcome is very satisfying to do.

Neutrals
-Leader variety is nice, giving us 36 options from the beginning is a lot more variety than I expected. But a lot of them just feel weird. First playthrough is Copernicus of poland, which is cool, I guess, but also kind of... odd?
-The act-end cullings, this is... idk. I praised the game for its commitment to actually feeling like playing through history before but this mechanic really goes straight against that. empires randomly falling at the end of each act with the others able to scoop up their land? Kinda cool, could take it or leave it.
-Diplomacy, AI, Religion, etc. None of these systems are particularly fleshed out but I would encourage people to remember the "base" versions of games like Civ and Stellaris when they were first released without any DLC and how barebones those felt compared to how you can play them today. I think ara delivers a sufficient amount of content for several playthroughs.

Bad:
-The UI is just not very useful. It takes an ungodly amount of clicks to do something as simple as giving a farm a plow or heavy plow.
-Resource & Crafting management: I really enjoy the resource management this game gives and the ability one has to tweak productions, but especially in the late game it becomes a very tiring aspect as you have to navigate the sheer volume of stuff your empire produces. The game is in desperate need of some kind of automation or settings changes to make this more friendly on the player and not so tiresome. Like plows simply being auto doled out to farms in need. I think my biggest issue with this part of the game is just how dramatically it slows the overall pace down.

Overall, I'm probably going to keep playing Ara for a little while at least. I'm eager to see if Oxide and Microsoft enable modding and what directions they take the game in with future DLC. I think if you like 4x you'll probably enjoy playing this game.

8 hours in , got to the end of act 1 after a couple of restarts.

Firstly, had to change some settings to get the visuals smooth. By default felt like edge scrolling/ moving around map was a bit choppy. Once that was fixed I started to get into it.

Huge learning curve. Really need to unlearn what you know in Civ and learn what Ara is all about. Its, got a different feel to it. I generally play peaceful in Civ, but in Ara I HAD to go to war. AI settling next to my capital? Nope thats not staying there! But I genuinely enjoyed the battles, even if they were simple to understand I think this is something that Civ 6 did wrong where battles and wars take a lot more micro management in Civ by bringing the units you need to the battle and shuffling around all the time, Ara gets you to preset your armies and give them formations and leaders and just put them up against the enemy. Less hassle

I saw someone say politics plays no part in Ara, I strongly disagree. Having an ally for the set amount of time that you do really helps. And maintaining that relationship I thought was really important, especially toward the end of the act. I had two AI declare war on me and with my ally it felt like "teams" trying to keep their positions on the board before the next act starts. I love the trade contracts. Playing as victoria I start with an extra trade route. Plus adding more routes those trade agreements really did me well. It makes trade valuable because I was getting a lot of good things from my ally and possibly more than she was getting from me because I had a focus in trade.

Im not sure about AI balancing though. When setting up the initial games, I tried a harder difficulty, when you mouse over the difficulties tool tip shows you some info, like "small bonuses, or no bonuses". I tried a much harder difficulty that said "no bonuses" but the AI were somehow constantly earning almost double prestige. Lowered to Prince and up to end of Act 1 I am winning mostly with 3200 prestige versus 2nd place of 3000 prestige. I might knock it up one level next game.

The length of the act felt long, possibly 5-6 hours, felt almost like a whole game and could stop here just after act one and say I was satisfied, but of course Im looking forward to playing next act now. I can see why the culling mechanic was added too. Its refreshes the game, like theres new focus, not like when you play civ and its the same all the way through.

Im not trying to crap all over Civ mind you. Civ is great, but Ara is fresh, its different

Let's keep it simple: ARA is a distant cousin to Civ in the 4X space. So, It's differences, seem to have aroused strong differences among reviewers.

If you: 1. expect a Civ clone; 2. are new to 4X; 3. hate games that aren't perfect on initial release; 4. trash games that don't play well/crash on your particular pc, regardless if it's working elsewhere; 5.expect perfection for $60; 6. are a generally trash poster on Steam....  then just return for your refund, post your toxic review, and leave the rest of us alone.

OTOH, if you are an experienced 4X gamer, or seriously want to become one, this game is for you: 1. simultaneous turns- press enter and it's instantly your turn again; 2. vast supply chain management; 3. merge multiple units into higher organizations; 4. keep one national identity (via one leader) for the whole game; 5. areas and zones instead of hexes; 6. want the challenge of a game with many more knobs and dials than CIV; 7. just scratching the surface- see other reviews.

Final rating: I don't know, it's a long game with a stiff learning curve, but I'm very pleased with my current experience thus far and feel I have received great value for the price.

Sounds ok at first, but you'll soon find units sitting around and waiting after destroying an enemy unit while 4 hexes away another enemy army is beating up your ally. It's all based around the AI settings that you put forth, but the AI is too simplistic to be intuitive, or even show some semblance of intelligence.

There's not room for roleplay or to immerse yourself. Just play ROTK 8, 10, or 11, they are just more in depth and provide more.

game_name: ROMANCE OF THE THREE KINGDOMS XIV
review_text:
Inability to Promote Officers During Battle: It's frustrating that we can't promote officers while they're in battle. We're forced to wait until everyone is back at base before promoting them.

Difficulty Employing Characters Like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan: Despite numerous attempts, we're unable to employ characters like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan. We keep receiving alerts that they're unemployed, yet they continue to reject our offers.

Uninteresting Battle Duels: The battle duels lack excitement. I remember a version of ROTK where duels were engaging, with buttons to press for counters and other actions. Incorporating such features would greatly enhance the gameplay experience.

Lackluster Area/City Government Mechanics: The mechanics for managing area and city governments are dull. It simply involves assigning an officer and then repeatedly sending idle officers out for employment until orders are depleted.

Stagnant Background Music (BGM): The BGM remains unchanged from many versions ago, which contributes to a feeling of stagnation in the game's overall experience.

Overall, the game feels more like a remastered version of an older ROTK installment rather than a significant improvement. Despite advancements in graphics, fundamental gameplay elements have seen little to no enhancement over the years.
